name: 5,6-dimethylchrysene
Reason: 5,6-dimethylchrysene has a melting point that can be predicted by considering its structural components. The basic unit for comparison is chrysene, which has a melting point of 106.5°C. The methyl groups (5 and 6) add approximately +10°C due to increasing the molecular weight and rigidity of the structure. The dimethyl substitution also introduces a slight increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, estimated at +5°C. The chrysene ring itself contributes to the melting point due to its rigidity and pi-pi interactions, estimated at +20°C. The methyl groups also contribute to the melting point due to their ability to participate in hydrogen bonding, estimated at +5°C.
